title: 111_s788
content: The Act titled "m-SPAM Act of 2009" exempts certain qualifying messages from being classified as mobile service commercial messages. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines terms related to commercial mobile service and mobile service commercial messages, including unsolicited short messages sent to wireless devices. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines terms related to commercial mobile service and mobile service commercial messages, including unsolicited short messages sent to wireless devices. The Act specifies that commercial electronic mail or short messages must not be sent without prior agreement from the recipient, except for messages related to facilitating, completing, or confirming a commercial transaction, or providing warranty information. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows commercial messages to be sent with prior agreement from the recipient, except for messages related to warranty information, product recalls, safety, or subscription changes. The sender can send messages regarding changes in subscription terms, recipient status, or account balance information. The sender can provide account balance information, employment-related details, or deliver goods and services to the recipient. The CAN-SPAM Act defines "short message" as a text sent to a wireless device, and "wireless device" as a phone used with commercial mobile service. Section 14 of the Act applies to certain messages sent by the sender to the recipient. The CAN-SPAM Act allows for the sending of short messages between wireless devices or from a commercial mobile service provider to its subscribers at no cost. Mobile service commercial messages can also be sent to subscribers at no cost unless they opt out. The CAN-SPAM Act allows commercial mobile service providers to send messages to subscribers at no charge unless they opt out. Amendments to the Act include changes to section 14(b) regarding commercial mobile service providers. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON UNAUTHORIZED MOBILE SERVICE COMMERCIAL MESSAGES CONTAINING UNSOLICITED ADVERTISEMENTS. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages without prior authorization. The definition of commercial mobile service is also updated. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit mobile service commercial messages without prior authorization. The updated definitions include terms like commercial mobile service, short message, and wireless device. The prohibition does not apply to sending short messages between wireless devices. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit mobile service commercial messages without prior authorization. The updated definitions include terms like commercial mobile service, short message, and wireless device. The prohibition does not apply to sending short messages between wireless devices or from a provider to its subscribers at no charge. States do not have greater authority over mobile service commercial messages than commercial electronic mail. The Communications Act of 1934 prohibits unauthorized mobile service commercial messages. States do not have more authority over mobile service messages than commercial electronic mail under the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. SEC. 4 prohibits unsolicited advertisements sent to cellular phones. The Federal Trade Commission will revise the do-not-call registry provisions to address costly or nuisance commercial mobile service messaging practices and explicitly prohibit sending commercial messages to numbers on the registry assigned to commercial mobile services, except for messages sent by the service provider to its subscribers at no cost. The Federal Trade Commission will update the do-not-call registry rules to prevent costly or annoying commercial mobile service messaging practices. Commercial messages cannot be sent to numbers on the registry assigned to commercial mobile services, except for messages sent by the service provider to its subscribers for free. Definitions for "mobile service commercial message" and "commercial mobile service" are provided.
